data.title: A Lesson Before Dying
data.meta_description: A Lesson Before Dying By Ernest J. Gaines
data.text:
→Examining an author’s life can inform and expand a reader’s understanding of a novel.

​

→Biographical criticism is the practice of analyzing a literary work through the lens of an author’s experience.

​

→ Today, we will explore the author’s life to understand the novel more fully.

​

~Ernest J. Gaines was born in 1933 on the River Lake plantation in Pointe Coupée Parish, Louisiana

-this was the setting for most of

his fiction

-he was the fifth generation in his

family to be born there.

~A Lesson Before Dying tells the story of a young black man convicted of participating in the murder of a white man. He is consequently sentenced to death in Louisiana in the 1940s.

​

~Although a work of fiction, this novel reflects the racial discrimination and stereotypes Gaines would have encountered in the pre-civil rights South.

​

"We all know--at least intellectually--that we're going [to die]. The difference is being told, 'Okay, it's tomorrow at 10 a.m.'

How do you react to that?

How do you face it?

​

That, it seems to me, is the ultimate test

of life.”

​
